newsitem.title: UK: Emerging market Eurobond issuers await stability.
newsitem.headline: Emerging market Eurobond issuers await stability.

text.p: Emerging market borrowers wanting to raise new funds are waiting for the market to stabilise after volatility last week caused by fears of currency devaluations, bankers said on Monday.
"Some issuers have backed away, but this will be a short-lived effect and once the market quietens down we will see a resumption of new issuance," a syndicate manager at a U.S. bank said.
"Time is running out before the summer holiday."
Fears that Brazil might devalue its currency after devaluations in the Philippines, Thailand and the Czech Republic led to sharp falls in Latin American debt and equity markets last week.
Spreads on emerging market Eurobonds widened by up to 30 basis points, and remain at these levels, after profit-taking ahead of holidays.

Borrowers which delayed new bond issues last week include Argentina, which had planned a $750 million global bond issue, and Brazilian private power utility Escelsa, which planned a $350 million bond.
Spread talk for the seven-year Argentina deal was around 175 basis points over U.S. Treasury notes last week, whereas now it would have to pay around 210 b.p. over, bankers said.
"The market is still quit weak," a dealer at a European bank said. "Argentina 2006 dollar bonds, for example, are trading at 280 b.p. over, up from 250 b.p. a week ago."
There was some talk that Argentina might come to the market this week, but many bankers said borrowers would wait-and-see.
"The Brazilian markets will be closely watched, and investors will also want to wait for the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to see where U.S. Treasuries are going," a Eurobond trader said.
On Tuesday Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan gives his semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on the U.S. economy. The market was expecting Greenspan to be vigilant on inflation.
U.S. Treasury bonds were jittery on Monday ahead of the speech, which will be closely watched for hints on future interest rate moves.
"If markets don't get worse, there will be a flurry of activity next week, as borrowers rush to get deals done before the August holiday," one dealer said.
